metadata.case_name: K.S. Rashid & Son v. Income-tax Investigation Commission

facts.text: Partnership firm K.S. Rashid & Son started on 5th May 1934 with partners K.S. Rashid Ahmed, Saeed Ahmed, and Mrs. Zafar Muhammed.
Mrs. Zafar Muhammed died on 7th January 1946, resulting in dissolution of the original partnership.
New firm with same name started on 8th January 1946 with surviving partners K.S. Rashid Ahmed, Saeed Ahmed, and Saeeda Begum as third partner.
Income-tax assessments completed up to 31st March 1943 in all cases.
Central Government referred cases of the firm and individuals to Income-tax Investigation Commission under section 5 of Act XXX of 1947 on 31st December 1947.
Authorised official (respondent No. 2) started investigations, extending to period subsequent to 31st March 1943.
Petition complaining of extension of investigations made to authorised official on 8th April 1949; no order passed as Commission expected change in law.
Law amended by Ordinance dated 5th July 1949.
Account books shown to official under protest.

Three applications filed before Commission on 17th September 1949: (1) no investigation re Mrs. Zafar Muhammed as dead; (2) no jurisdiction over Saeeda Begum as new partner not previously assessed; (3) no enquiry into new firm from 8th January 1946.

Four miscellaneous petitions (C.M. Nos. 256, 260, 261, 262 of 1950) filed before High Court of Punjab in June 1950 under articles 226 and 227 seeking: writ of prohibition, certiorari to quash proceedings, or revision under article 227.
Rules issued by High Court on 25th July 1950 after report from Commission.
High Court dismissed petitions on 10th August 1950 on grounds of lack of jurisdiction and special remedies under the Act.
Certificate granted by High Court under article 133(1)(c); appeals to Supreme Court.
Appellants availed remedy under section 8(5) of Act XXX of 1947; reference made to High Court of Allahabad awaiting decision.
Petitioners are assessees within U.P. State; assessments by Income-tax Officers of that State; subsequent proceedings by U.P. authorities; case stated to High Court at Allahabad.

legal_issues.text: Whether Punjab High Court had jurisdiction under article 226 to issue writs of certiorari or prohibition regarding income-tax investigation proceedings.
Whether remedies under section 8(5) of Act XXX of 1947 exclude jurisdiction under articles 226 and 227 of the Constitution.

petitioner_arguments.text: Punjab High Court has jurisdiction under article 226 as Commission located in Delhi within its territories; distinguished Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakimedi relying on Election Commission v. Venkata Rao.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 226 of Constitution; Election Commission v. Venkata Rao (1953 SCR 1144)

petitioner_arguments.text: Article 226 remedy not excluded by special remedies in Act XXX of 1947.
Investigations improperly extended beyond 31st March 1943; amendment not retrospective; no jurisdiction over dead partner, new partner, or new firm.

respondent_arguments.text: No jurisdiction in Punjab High Court as assessees in U.P., assessments by U.P. officers, proceedings in U.P., references to Allahabad High Court; mere location of Commission in Delhi insufficient per Parlakimedi case.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakimedi (70 IA 129)

respondent_arguments.text: Special Act XXX of 1947 provides exclusive remedies; articles 226/227 not available.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 8(5) of Act XXX of 1947; sections 66, 66A Income-tax Act

respondent_arguments.text: No relief due to sections 5(3) and 9 of Act XXX of 1947.

court_reasoning.text: Punjab High Court has jurisdiction under article 226 as writs can issue to authorities within its territories; distinguished Parlakimedi case as pre-Constitution limited jurisdiction; Constitution widened powers per Election Commission v. Venkata Rao.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Two limitations under art 226: territories and amenability by residence/location.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide if s.8(5) exclusive; art 226 discretionary; appellants availed s.8(5) remedy with reference pending in Allahabad High Court; refuse interference.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court discretion to refuse writ if adequate alternative relief available.

holdings.text: High Courts have jurisdiction under article 226 to issue writs to authorities located within their territories, notwithstanding subject-matter location.
Article 226 remedy discretionary; not to be invoked where alternative statutory remedy availed and pending.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ryots of Garabandho v. Zamindar of Parlakimedi
precedents_cited.relevance: Pre-Constitution jurisdiction limits; mere location insufficient in that context, but inapplicable post-Constitution.
Explains widened writ jurisdiction under article 226; limitations of territories and amenability.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nundo Lal Bose v. The Calcutta Corporation
precedents_cited.relevance: Certiorari issued based on location; contrasted with Parlakimedi.

precedents_cited.case_name: Besant v. The Advocate General of Madras

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Basis for appeals, writ jurisdiction, preservation and expansion of High Court powers.

statutes_cited.name: Taxation on Income (Investigation Commission) Act, 1947 (Act XXX of 1947)
statutes_cited.relevance: Referral for investigation; limits on scope; alternative remedy via reference to High Court.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Procedure for references from Commission orders.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court held Punjab High Court had jurisdiction under article 226 but refused to interfere as appellants had availed alternative remedy under section 8(5) of Act XXX of 1947 with reference pending before Allahabad High Court; upheld High Court dismissal.

key_quotes.text: "the question of jurisdiction must be regarded as one of substance, and that it would not have been within the competence of the Supreme Court to claim jurisdiction over such a matter as the present by issuing certiorari to the Board of Revenue on the strength of its location in the town."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quoting and distinguishing Parlakimedi case on jurisdiction.

key_quotes.text: "There are only two limitations placed upon the exercise of these powers by a High Court under article 226 of the Constitution one is that the power is to be exercised throughout the territories in relation to which it exercises jurisdiction... The other limitation is that the person or authority... must be amenable to its jurisdiction either by residence or location within those territories."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the remedy provided for in article 226 of the Constitution is a discretionary remedy and the High Court has always the discretion to refuse to grant any writ if it is satisfied that the aggrieved party can have an adequate or suitable relief elsewhere."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Basis for refusing relief due to alternative remedy.
